questions.text: While reading the ECG of a 22-year-old male who has come for a wellness assessment outreach camp, you notice regular sharp high-frequency spike giving the appearance of a thick baseline.  Which of the following should you suspect?
questions.solution:
Regular sharp high-frequency spike giving the appearance of a thick baseline is characteristically seen in case of electrical interference. It can be caused by electric motors in beds/mattresses, electrical wiring, etc. Electrical interference causes regular oscillation of the ECG trace, giving the appearance of a thickened baseline.

 

Other Options:

Poor Electrode contact would result in Bizzare ECG patterns, most clearly visible in the rhythm strip.  

Normally calibrated ECG recorders show a deflection of 1cm for a 1mV signal. A calibration signal is usually displayed at the beginning of the ECG record.

Undercalibration causes the complexes to look smaller while over calibration would cause the complexes to look larger.

questions.text: In ECG tracings,  sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are typically seen in

choices.text: Recording done with paper speed of 12.5 mm/s
Recording done with paper speed of 50 mm/s

questions.solution:
Sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are seen in a patient that is not relaxed. 

Though the ECG recorders are configured to pick up the electrical frequency generated by the heart better, they also detect the contractions of skeletal muscles. So, unless the patient is relaxed and lying down comfortably, the tracing may show some skeletal muscle activity.

Ex:- 

A patient that is shivering due to cold, or one that has involuntary movements due to conditions like Parkinson's, etc would cause spikes in the baseline of the ECG.

In the case of shivering, the spikes would be more exaggerated and synchronized than that seen in a patient that is not adequately relaxed, because of the skeletal muscle groups contracting together in case of shivering.

 

Other options:

  • Patients with hypothyroidism would show bradycardia, low voltage QRS complexes, and widespread T-wave inversions.
  • The recording is normally done with a paper speed of 25 mm/s.
    • Recording at 12.5 mm/s, which is slower than normal, would cause QRS complex that are close together (creating the false impression of a rapid heart rate) and P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves that are narrow and spiky
    • Recording at 50 mm/s, which is faster than normal, would produce longer intervals between QRS complexes (creating the false impression of a slow heart rate), widened QRS complexes, and an apparently long QT interval.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is assessed with an ECG during his wellness check-up visit. Calculate the heart rate from the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The RR interval has 19 small boxes in between, and hence the heart rate is 1500/19~79/min.

The relationship between the heart rate and the RR interval is given by: 

Heart rate = 1500/(number of small boxes in between successive R waves) 

Methods to calculate heart rate from ECG: 

Box counting methods: This can be done via the number of small boxes or the large boxes between two successive R waves. If using the large boxes, the equation is  

Heart rate = 300/(number of large boxes in between successive R waves) 

QRS counting methods: This is used when the heart rate is irregular. Thus there will be a variability in the RR intervals, making the box-counting method unreliable. Here, the number of QRS intervals in a set interval, for example, 10 seconds, is counted. This number is then multiplied by an appropriate factor to get an estimate for 60s. In this example, we would multiple the number of QRS complexes in 10s by 6. 

Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of more than 100 beats/minute and bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/minute.

questions.text: The ECG given below shows:

choices.text: A prolonged PR interval measuring 240 ms
A normal PR interval measuring 240 ms
A prolonged PR interval measuring 160 ms
A normal PR interval measuring 160 ms

questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a prolonged PR interval measuring 240 msec.

The given ECG shows a PR interval measuring 6 small boxes. One small box represents 0.04 sec. Therefore, 6 boxes is 6*0.04 sec = 0.240 sec or 240 msec. 

The PR interval is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. The normal PR interval is 120-200ms.

The image below represents the PR interval:

 

A prolonged PR interval occurs due to a delay in the conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles. It is also termed a first-degree heart (AV) block. It is important to note that there is no interruption in conduction. 

People with first-degree AV block are generally asymptomatic and do not require any intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following condition has the given ECG changes?
questions.solution:
The given ECG clearly depicts the Delta wave at the start of QRS complex. It is characteristic of WPW syndrome.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles.

ECG Feature:

  • P-R interval <120 ms
  • Slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the "Delta wave"
    • WPW pattern "Type A": Positive delta waves in all precordial leads, with small or absent S waves
    • WPW pattern "Type B": A delta wave is negative, with prominent S waves, in right precordial leads
  • The QRS complex as a whole is slightly widened
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following causes an increase in the RR interval
questions.solution:
An increase in the R-R interval in the ECG means a decreased heart rate, which can be caused by vagal stimulation.

 

Note:- SA node stimulation would increase the heart rate and thereby decrease the RR interval

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. Which of the following is the least likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has an organized, apparently normal ECG without a pulse - i.e the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). Of the given etiologies, the least likely is Hyperthermia. However, hypothermia is a common cause to be ruled out.

The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until more definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted. It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated.

Related Pearl: Reversible Causes of Cardiac Arrest

  • 5 H’s:
    • Hypovolemia
    • Hypoxia
    • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
    • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
    • Hypothermia
  • 5 T’s:
    • Tension pneumothorax
    • Tamponade (cardiac)
    • Toxins
    • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
    • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG classically depicts polymorphic ventricular tachycardia—torsades de pointes. Torsade rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia meaning “twisting of the points,” characterized by twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance.

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

The other cause of torsades de pointes include:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform).
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulphate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate - electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion or intravenous atropine 

Note: Although hypocalcemia is associated with prolongation of QT interval, there are only rare reports of torsades de pointes associated with hypocalcemia. So, among the above options, the best answer would be hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency with chest discomfort following a football match. His ECG is as below. Which of the following is an accurate description of the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
The given ECG depicts De Winter’s T waves. There is no ST elevation in V2, but there is a hyperacute T-wave.  This is a De Winter's T-wave and diagnostic of near occlusion of the LAD.  V3 also has ST depression with a hyperacute T-wave very suggestive of de Winter's T-waves.

  • The de Winter ECG pattern is an anterior STEMI equivalent that presents without obvious ST-segment elevation.

Diagnostic Criteria

  • Tall, prominent, symmetric T waves in the precordial leads
  • Upsloping ST-segment depression >1mm at the J-point in the precordial leads
  • Absence of ST elevation in the precordial leads
  • ST segment elevation (0.5mm-1mm) in aVR

questions.text: The onset of the QRS complex in an ECG corresponds to which phase of cardiac action potential:
questions.solution:
The onset of the QRS complex in an ECG corresponds to phase 0 of the cardiac action potential.

Cardiac Action Potential and The ECG

  • The rapid upstroke (phase 0) of the action potential corresponds to the onset of QRS. 
  • The plateau (phase 2) corresponds to the isoelectric ST segment.
  • Active repolarization (phase 3) corresponds to the inscription(tracing) of the T wave

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate >100 bpm
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with >3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

MAT is characterised by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia has a rate of 150-200 bpm. It also has a regular rhythm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. It can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation has an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rate is >300 bpm. The 'P' wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter has a regular rhythm. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw-tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in a patient with a Dextrocardia?

choices.text: Inverted P wave in lead I and lead aVL
Negative QRS comples in Lead I
Negative T wave in Lead I
Progressively increasing voltage across precordium in chest leads

questions.solution:
Progressively decreasing (not increasing) voltage across the precordium is seen in dextrocardia. This is because the heart is located on the right side, while the leads are placed on the left. Right-sided lead placement would show a normal progression.

Findings Suggestive of Dextrocardia

  • Inverted P waves in Lead I and aVL
  • Negative QRS complex and T wave in Lead I
    • (Lead I: inversion of all complexes, aka ‘global negativity’ i.e. inverted P wave, negative QRS, inverted T wave)
  • Progressively decreasing voltage across the precordium

questions.text: Which of the following is not a finding you would expect to see in a patient with a left bundle branch block?

choices.text: Broad monophasic R wave in V5-V6

questions.solution:
RSR’ pattern in V1-3 is seen in the case of the right bundle branch block (RBBB), not the left bundle branch block (LBBB). 

ECG findings suggestive of LBBB:

  • QRS duration of >120 ms 
  • Dominant S wave in V1 with loss of R wave
  • Notched R wave and no Q wave in V6

The below image shows the characteristic changes in LBBB:

 

ECG findings suggestive of RBBB:

  • rSR’ pattern in V1-2 
  • Wide S wave in the lateral leads I, V6
  • T wave inversion in the right precordial leads and upright T waves in left precordial leads due to discordance to terminal QRS vector
  • Broad QRS complex of more than > 120 ms

The image below and the ECG show the above mentioned changes in RBBB: 

Bundle branch blocks occur due to impaired conduction in the intraventricular conduction system. This leads to the prolongation of the QRS complex by more than 120 ms. However, incomplete blocks can also occur, leading to a QRS complex duration of 110–120 ms. 

The orientation of the QRS vector depends on the branch block. In LBBB, the QRS vector is directed to the left and posteriorly. In RBBB, the QRS vector is oriented anteriorly and to the right, leading to an rSR' pattern in V1 and qRS in V6. 

RBBBs are more common in patients without structural heart disease. LBBB is associated with coronary heart disease, hypertensive heart disease, aortic valve disease, and cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Identify the rhythm abnormality in the ECG strip:
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts monomorphic VT.

Monomorphic VT has the same QRS complex from beat to beat, indicating that the activation sequence is the same from beat to beat and that each beat likely originates from the same source. Other features include:

  • Rapid heart rate (> 100 bpm)
  • Broad QRS complexes (> 120 ms)

questions.solution:
The ECG depicts ventricular fibrillation. It has the following characteristics:

The blue arrows in the above ECG point to the J wave or the Osborn wave or the camel hump waves. This wave is seen in Hypothermia.

questions.text: Electrical alternans in ECG is characteristic of
questions.solution:
• Total electrical alternans (P-QRS-T) with sinus tachycardia is a relatively specific sign of pericardial effusion,  usually with cardiac tamponade. 

  

  • The mechanism relates to a periodic swinging motion of the heart in the effusion at a frequency exactly one-half the heart rate.   

                

 

 Electrical alternans   

  • Periodic beat to beat change in electrical/hemodynamic behaviour 

  

  • Total electrical alterans: specific, but not sensitive of effusion 

  

  • ST-T alterans: LV failure, it is considered as noninvasive marker of ventricular arrhythmia 
  • T-U alterans: Torsades de pointes/ acquired long QT syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the ER with dizziness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 45/minute. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shown above is the second-degree atrioventricular block type 1 - Wenckebach phenomenon.

Treatment is indicated when bradycardia is accompanied by any one of the following:

  • Hypotension
  • Acutely altered mental status
  • Signs of shock
  • Ischemic chest discomfort
  • Acute heart failure

Treatment is initiated with 1 mg atropine iv which may be repeated at 3-5 minute intervals to a maximum dose of 3 mg.

Along with atropine, transcutaneous pacing is to be done.

If the bradycardia is refractory to both atropine and transcutaneous pacing, then IV infusions of dopamine (5 to 20 μg/kg/min) or epinephrine (2 to 10 μg/min) should be considered.

If the patient still isn’t responding, then transvenous pacing should be tried. If the patient is under spinal anesthesia, low-dose (0.2 mg) IV epinephrine can be given.

Epinephrine is the drug of choice for treating bradyarrhythmias in infants and children.

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG 

If the bradyarrhythmia is persisent causing hemodynamic instability, then the management is as depicted by the flowchart (based on the AHA guidelines) below:

questions.text: A 22-year-old man was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate was 160/min and blood pressure was 110/80 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient has paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. As the patient's blood pressure is normal and there is no evidence of hemodynamic deterioration, initial treatment consists of vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. This is because vagal maneuvers alone can terminate approximately 20% to 25% of reentry supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).

If this is unsuccessful, then IV adenosine 6 mg is given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg, respectively.

If there is hemodynamic deterioration, then cardioversion is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate is 170/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
This patient has supraventricular tachycardia with evidence of hemodynamic deterioration. Immediate treatment would be cardioversion (50-100J).

If the patient were hemodyamically stable, initial treatment would be vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. This is because vagal maneuvers alone can terminate approximately 20% to 25% of reentry supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).

If this is unsuccessful, then iv adenosine 6 mg is given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg respectively.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing surgery, which is the single best lead in the ECG to diagnose arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Lead II is the best for detecting arrhythmias and inferior wall myocardial infarction.

Lead V5 is th best for detecting anterior and lateral wall myocardial infarction.

For arrhythmia, oesophagal leads are better than lead II but they are not yet put into wide use.

For myocardial ischemia, new regional wall motion abnormalities and decreased systolic wall thickening on transesophageal echocardiography are more sensitive than ECG.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing mitral valve repair, which is the most sensitive indicator of myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Transesophageal echocardiography is the most sensitive indicator of myocardial ischemia.  

New regional wall motion abnormalities (RWMA) and decreased systolic wall thickening on transesophageal echocardiography are more sensitive than ECG.

Ischemia may be indicated clinically by a sudden onset intraoperative arrhythmia or conduction block.

questions.text: The given ECG is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The ECG is characteristic of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy

  • The Epsilon wave (a small positive deflection buried in the end of the QRS complex) is the characteristic finding in ARVC.
  • T wave inversions in V1-3 is seen 85% of patients of ARVC.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents to the OPD with chest pain, palpitations and shortness of breath. An ECG is taken to determine the cause of his symptoms. What does the ECG show?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of RVH

  • R-V1 >= 7
  • R-V1 + S-V5/V6 > 11
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more
  • T wave inversion in RV leads (Lead III, V1 & V2)

Causes of RVH

  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Mitral stenosis
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Chronic lung disease (Cor pulmonale)
  • Congenital heart disease (e.g. Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis)
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy

questions.text: If the stroke volume is 70 ml/beat, the cardiac output of the given patient is:
questions.solution:
The heart rate according to the given ECG is 300 / No. of large squares = 300/4 = 75 beats/min

Cardiac output is calculated by:

Cardiac output = Stroke volume x Heart rate

                         = 70 x 75 ml / min

                         = 5250 ml/min

                         = 5.2 L/min

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete comes for a routine examination. He has no symptoms. The ECG is as shown below. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 45 bpm. The patient is an athlete and heart rates are usually lower in athletes.

As the patient is asymptomatic no further therapy should be given to increase the heart rate.

Sinus bradycardia:

  • Sinus bradycardia is defined as SA nodal rhythm with a rate <60 beats/min. However, in young healthy adults and athletes, a resting heart rate of <60 beats/min is common.
  • Also, a sinus pause of upto 3 seconds on ECG is commonly seen in athletes and elderly individuals.
  • If the rate is <40 beats/min, in an awake individual in the absence of physical training, then it is considered abnormal.

Diagnosis of SA node dysfunction:

  • The presence of abnormal sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is insufficient to diagnose SA node dysfunction. Longer-term electrocardiographic recording and clinical correlation are required to establish the diagnosis.
  • On the contrary, the presence of symptoms without any sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is sufficient to rule out SA node dysfunction.

questions.text: Helen is a 78-year-old woman who is a smoker for the past 30 years and has a history of angina. She presents to your accident and emergency (A&E) department with chest pain worse on inspiration and shortness of breath. Her ECG shows signs of:
questions.solution:
• The ECG changes are classic of pulmonary embolism showing S1Q3T3.

ECG findings in pulmonary embolism

  • Sinus tachycardia
  • Complete or incomplete RBBB (seen in the given ECG also)
  • S1Q3T3: deep S wave in lead I, Q wave in III, inverted T wave in III

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the clinic with complaints of dyspnea. Interpret the ECG finding.
questions.solution:
The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen in left atrial enlargement.

This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis lead to left atrial dilation. 

The features of P mitrale are:

  • lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves
  • Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed depolarization of the LA)

P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement. 

Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead V6.

Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below).

questions.text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.

Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.

The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

questions.text: The ECG wave as shown in the image below is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
The above ECG wave characteristically depicts Digoxin effect.

Digoxin effect refers to the presence on the ECG of:

  • Downsloping ST depression with a characteristic “Salvador Dali sagging” or “Hockey Stick” appearance.
  • Flattened, inverted, or biphasic T waves.
  • Shortened QT interval.

Additional ECG Features:

  • Mild PR interval prolongation of up to 240ms (due to increased vagal tone).
  • Prominent U waves.
  • Peaking of the terminal portion of the T waves.
  • J point depression (usually in leads with tall R waves).

QRS complex / ST segment changes:

  • The morphology of the QRS complex / ST segment is variously described as either “slurred”, “sagging” or “scooped” and resembling either a “reverse tick”, “hockey stick” or “Salvador Dali’s moustache”.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with acute severe chest pain associated with sweating 30 min earlier. The ECG of the person is shown below. Which of the following drugs should be given to this person?
questions.solution:
• The given ECG shows ST elevation in lead I, aVL, V3, V4 and reciprocal depression in lead III suggestive of evolving Anterior Myocardial infarction.
  • In MI, the drug of choice is thrombolytics like Streptokinase.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a premature ventricular complex (PVC) that occurs every second beat (ventricular bigeminy).

PVCs exhibit premature timing by arising before the anticipated occurrence of the subsequent regular heartbeat. They display an aberrant QRS-T appearance, where the QRS complex appears unusually wide (0.12 sec or longer), and the T wave and QRS complex point in opposite orientations (discordant).

Frequent PVCs can manifest in different patterns. When two PVCs occur consecutively, they are termed a pair or couplet.

If three or more PVCs occur in succession (triplet), it is classified as ventricular tachycardia (VT). The repetitive pattern of one normal beat followed by one PVC is known as ventricular bigeminy.

When the repeating sequence involves two normal beats followed by a PVC, it is called ventricular trigeminy. Similarly, if three normal beats are followed by a PVC, it is referred to as ventricular quadrigeminy.

questions.text: A patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed a narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160 BPM. His blood pressure is 96/68 mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complex regular tachycardia without P waves are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next step in the management of PSVT in a hemodynamically stable (systolic blood pressure >90 mm Hg) patient is vagotonic maneuvres such as carotid sinus massage or Valsalva maneuver.

Carotid sinus massage can be considered in the absence of carotid bruits and no history of stroke. If vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used. 

Non-DHP calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are second-line pharmacological agents in the management of PSVT. They can cause hypotension before and after terminating the arrhythmia.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mm Hg), immediate QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is necessary.

questions.text: In a normal ECG obtained from a patient, a biphasic P wave may be seen in which of the following lead(s)?
questions.solution:
In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only.

Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 consists of:

  • Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector)
  • Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector)

questions.text: Clinical finding seen in hypermagnesemia is
questions.solution:
Hypermagnesimia causes bradycardia and hypotension (like neurogenic shock).

Causes -

  • Excessive magnesium intake
    • A. Cathartics, urologic irrigants
    • B. Parenteral magnesium administration
  • Rapid mobilization from soft tissues
    • A. Trauma, shock, sepsis
    • B. Cardiac arrest
    • C. Burns
  • Impaired magnesium excretion
    • A. Renal failure
    • B. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Other
    • A. Adrenal insufficiency
    • B. Hypothyroidism
    • C. Hypothermia

Clinical features -

  • The most prominent clinical manifestations of hypermagnesemia are vasodilation and neuromuscular blockade.
  • Hypotension is refractory to vasopressors or volume expansion may be an early sign.
  • Nausea, lethargy, and weakness may progress to respiratory failure, paralysis, coma, with hypoactive tendon reflexes, paradoxical bradycardia and heart block may be seen.

ECG: Prolongation of PR, QRS, and QT intervals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of palpitations. He is hemodynamically stable. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows wide complex tachycardia (QRS complexes are >120 ms in duration), with regular QRS complexes with uniform morphology in each lead. This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Since this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best management is IV amiodarone. 

In patients with sustained VT who are hemodynamically stable, medical treatment with intravenous amiodarone is preferred. Alternative drugs that can be given are lignocaine and procainamide. However, if the VT fails to resolve with medical management or if the patient's symptoms worsen, DC cardioversion is the next step. 

Other options:

Option A: Carotid massage has no role in the management of VT. It is used as an initial step in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to block the AV node and terminate the arrhythmia.

Option B: Chest compressions are done until the defibrillator is arranged to ensure some amount of cardiac output even during this period.

Option C: If a patient with VT has hemodynamic compromise due to hypotension or impaired consciousness or has pulmonary, electrical cardioversion is performed.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is the probable diagnosis when the observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match ECG changes.

Myocardial stunning is a state where certain segments of the myocardium (usually corresponding to an area of major coronary occlusion) show forms of contractile abnormality (dysfunction) on echocardiography.

In Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, while the ECG changes mimic a myocardial infarction(MI), the left ventricular dysfunction extends well beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG. Ventriculography shows apical dilation with basal contraction.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs typically in older women and is associated with a sudden increase in emotional or physical stress, presenting with hypotension, chest pain with ECG changes of acute MI, and pulmonary edema. Its also known as apical ballooning syndrome or acute stress-induced cardiomyopathy.

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction with reduced contractility and ejection fraction, most commonly seen in amyloidosis, and enlarged ventricles on imaging with low-voltage ECG complexes.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is a type of familial dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), having defects in desmosomal proteins, affecting the ventricles showing thin ventricular walls on Echo, epsilon waves, and low voltage ECG complexes.

Option D: Pericardial tamponade is characterized by hypotension, muffled heart sounds and increased jugular venous pressure with muffled heart sounds with total electrical alternans and sinus tachycardia in ECG.

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality?
questions.solution:
Pseudo P pulmonale refers to tall peaked P waves seen in hypokalemia.
P-pulmonale refers to P waves taller than >2.5mm in an ECG lead.

Hypocalcemia (Option C) prolongs the QT interval.

Hypercalcemia (Option D) shortens the QT interval.

questions.text: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressant and antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. On evaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this condition, among the above drugs.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
The given ECG showing a wide QRS complex tachycardia with waxing and waning QRS amplitude points to the diagnosis of torsades des pointes. As the patient is hemodynamically stable, intravenous MgSO4 is the treatment of choice.

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) has a continually changing QRS morphology. Polymorphic VT that occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired prolongation of QT interval is referred to as torsades des pointes. Patients present with near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest.

IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and the prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades des pointes.

If magnesium alone is ineffective, isoproterenol infusion or pacing, to a rate of 100-120 depolarization/minute usually suppresses VT recurrences.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation
Used in unstable PSVT, atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, and ventricular tachycardia with a pulse Used in ventricular tachycardia without a pulse, and ventricular fibrillation.
Shock is delivered in sync with the R wave (in absolute refractory period) Shock is delivered at any time during the cardiac cycle.
Monophasic - 100 to 200J Monophasic - 360J
Biphasic - 50 to 100J Biphasic - 120 to 200J

questions.text: What is the possible diagnosis for a patient with the ECG findings as shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG image give shows diffuse ST-segment elevation characteristic of acute pericarditis.

Other options:

  • Inferior wall MI will show ST elevations in leads II, III, aVF
  • The ECG findings for pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade are:
    • Sinus tachycardia
    • Electrical alternans
    • Low QRS voltages
  • The ECG changes of hypothyroidism will include bradycardia with low voltage complexes.

questions.text: This phenomenon seen in atrial fibrillation is known as:
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts Ashman phenomenon.

  • Ashman phenomenon occurs when you get two beats with a long RR interval followed by a beat with a short RR interval. In this situation, the beat with the short RR interval is aberrantly conducted - typically with a RBBB morphology.
  • The Ashman phenomenon is typically seen in the setting of atrial fibrillation, where the RR interval varies from beat to beat.
  • The significance of the Ashman phenomenon is that the broad QRS complexes are commonly mistaken for ventricular ectopic/PVCs. However, they're not ectopic beats. Instead, these broad QRS complexes represent the aberrant conduction of a supraventricular beat.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER with complaints of multiple episodes of vomiting, increased frequency of urination, and constipation for the past 5 days. He also complained of lethargy and muscle pain. He is a known case of SCC of the lung. What is likely to be seen in the ECG of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptides. It is mostly associated with squamous-cell lung cancer (SCC). ECG is likely to show a decreased QT interval.

Hypocalcemia shows increased QT interval.

questions.text: ECG of a patient revealed a QT interval of 0.55s. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
QT interval of 0.55s suggests QT prolongation. It is not seen in digitalis toxicity. Rather, a QT shortening with characteristic “scooping” of the ST–T-wave complex, called a digitalis effect, is seen.

The ECG changes seen in digitalis toxicity are as follows:

  • Prolonged PR interval
  • ST-segment depression
  • Short QT interval

QT interval represents the time taken for the ventricles to depolarize and repolarize. It is prolonged in the following:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Congenital long QT syndromes such as Romano-Ward syndrome
  • Hypothermia
  • Drugs: Class IA and Class III antiarrhythmics
  • Intracranial bleeds: particularly SAH
